node.text:
Today is the day! Unnur will finally be "premiering" at Tribeca this evening. The film was supposed to premiere at Tribeca last year but unfortunately the whole event was cancelled due to covid. Unnur has since been released but it is still such an honor for it to be included at Tribeca this year. I'm sad I'm not there today but I am excited to be able to release the Behind the Scenes cut of the film! This BTS cut gives a deeper look into both why and how the film was made. If you haven't had a chance to see the full film yet, you can find it on my IGTV and YouTube channel. Big thanks again to everyone involved this was such a special project from start to finish

Directed by: @chrisburkard
Assistant Director: @benweiland
Written by: @63mph
Director of Photography: @jefftaylr
Executive Producers: @mparns, @eslate
Produced by: @MikeySandifer, @ChrisBurkard
Story by: @BenWeiland, @ChrisBurkard, @63mph
Cinematography: @BenWeiland, @jefftaylr, @ChrisBurkard, @Egillhalldorsson, @timbuz
Drone Operators: @ChrisBurkard, @BenWeiland
Water Cinematography: @BenWeiland, @ChrisBurkard
Editors: @bobcat
Music Licensing: @ryanespi, @MikeySandifer
DIT: @MattrFoley
Still Photography: @MattrFoley, @ChrisBurkard
Set PA: @MattrFoley
Sound Design: Jan Bezouska
Colorist: @davec9k
Graphic Artists: @BenWeiland, @KyleKerr, Riley Brown
Surfers: @HeidarLogi 

Thanks to support from @billabong and @sonyalpha

node.text:
Here it is, all the gear I did and didn’t use for the Iceland winter fatbike expedition. Last year I made a gear review and I realized that going through everything afterwards would have been way more effective to really understand what I needed, loved, craved, relied upon and didn't use at all!

Here's a list of all the brands I mentioned, check them out: @45nrth @dissentlabs @rapha @66north @blackdiamond @pocsports @suunto @hydrapak @revelatedesigns @nitecoreflashlight @jaybirdsport @bigagnes_ @jetboil @schwalbetires @lezyneofficial @oldmanmountainracks @voilestraps @coalheadwear @gerbergear @fezzari_bicycles @srammtb @zippspeed @infinitybikeseat @icelandair @sonyxperia @envecomposites 

Video edit by @jeffreybrundage

node.text:
The following video is a vulnerable recollection of the first 24 hours of Iceland‘s newest volcanic eruption.  I was sent out with one of my best friends to document what a Peak experience means to me. I’m still not sure why I was given the gift of experiencing this or how I lucked into such a unique moment in time.. but I wanted to share what it Felt like more than what it looked like. 

One thing is for certain - no photograph or video will ever come close to what this makes you feel inside.  Massive thanks for @suunto for supporting this project as apart of their new 9 Peak launch. One of the burliest pieces of equipment I I have used to track, document and share my adventures.

Love you long time @ellithor for filming and directing this piece and sharing that moment with me. 
@_ryanhill_ @sparklejensen

node.text:
This film follows the story of Mylo Fowler (@navajomylo), who photographs the beauty of the Navajo Nation on a quest to share the story of its past and protect its future. Mylo grew up on the reservation, raised by its red dirt and wild horses. But a spiritual elder’s prophecy upends his entire vision of the future, and Mylo enters the unknown to discover his rightful place in the world.

Watch the full film and hear from Mylo on what photography means to him 👉 " The beautiful thing about a camera is that it’s a tool that allows me to preserve my heritage and pass it on to the next generation. My hope is that my images can inspire the youth. More importantly, that they will understand that at one time our land was taken away from us. And just that story of Hwéeldi. I just have the utmost appreciation for the land that we do still have, and as we roam about, as we go about, my hope is that we are what we are supposed to be...and that’s caretakers of the land.” - @navajomylo

node.text:
How far would you go, and what would you endure to surf alone? On this search, the journey often consumes the destination when the magnitude of the adventure overwhelms us. In a new film by @Roark , Directed and shot in Alaska by @benweiland & myself -surfers Harrison Roach, Parker Coffin and Nate Zoller test their resolve as they retrace the path of a legend in one of the most remote destinations in the world. The oft not surfed Aleutian Islands serve as more than a setting -they are a relentless femme fatale in a film about what motivates us to adventure into the unknown and more importantly, what lures us back after we are broken.

Film is now available for pre-order 
Link in bio!
Premier date 3/16

node.text:
My obsession with aerial photography has created defining moments in my body of work. In this workshop, learn the essential technical and creative knowledge to pursue the art of creating images from the air. 
​​This course covers in-depth research and planning, approach, essential pilot communication, gear management, and composition. All the necessary elements to make sure your flight investment provides you with opportunity to create work you are proud of.  @wildistco 
Here is a sneak peak. Link in bio!

node.text:
Wanna make friends fast? Quarantine with them on a boat for 14 days…. you get to know them pretty well. There are few joys greater than seeing people experience a place you love for the first time. That was the case with this new film project I directed for @billabong’s A/DIV team. @griffin_cola, @tyler_warren, @beccaspeak and @eithanosborne point their compasses north and head to an isolated stretch of icy points, reefs and bays where heavy weather calls the shots and your survival instincts remain fully charged.

Jump aboard 𝘛𝘩𝘦 𝘝𝘪𝘬𝘪𝘯𝘨 and relive the adventure.

Directed by @Chrisburkard

Edited by @davec9k 

Shot by @patstacyfilm

Produced by @Mikeysandifer @evanslater

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by ChrisBurkard in Arctic with @danedamus. May be an image of nature, ocean and water.

node.text:
For World Photography Day I wanted to share an image that for me was career altering. When I had decided to put my focus on cold weather travel it came with a ton of risk. Let’s just say I didn’t always have the support of magazines & editors when the trip presented so many challenges. Putting up every dollar yourself for an expedition can be challenging when you have no clue if it will be worth it. It can be strain on a bank account and a relationship. A month in Northern Norway during the winter was no exception. We were ill prepared & on a shoe string budget and we paid the price. Getting stuck in remote cabins, destroying a few rental vehicles from bad weather, getting stuck on a ferry for 3 days and ultimately negotiating a snowmobile rental to access a stretch of coast in Vardo. I was out of my depth and out of my realm… trying my best to keep my chin up despite making some poor decisions along the way and lacking some crucial research.
What resulted was one of the best trips of my life, despite the challenges. It reinforced my love of cold water and the remote landscapes that I would stare at on the magazine rack. I made a dream come to life and all sudden those distant shores weren’t so distant anymore. Just thinking about this trip makes my senses feel overwhelmed & body tremble from the cold, but it also elicits a huge smile.
Pictured is @danedamus in the Lofoten Islands circa 2010 ish.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by ChrisBurkard on August 18, 2021. May be an image of fire and nature.

node.text: Even after so many years of experiencing these “once in a lifetime” events.. I still seem to always take it for granted. I’ve heard from so many that the volcanic eruption in Iceland has now grown to mammoth proportions which has made for a much less intimate experience. The lava has spread out so wide that getting near the cone is near impossible. It makes me really grateful for the opportunity I had during those first few days as we watched it evolve and grow day by day. Documenting this experience from the perspective of the local Icelandic Search & Rescue was also an incredible & gave me access I could have only dreamt of. Thanks again.

node.text: Simple, yet profound.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by ChrisBurkard in Iceland. May be an image of nature, twilight, beach, ocean and coast.

node.text: A blown out sky revealing a the textures of a fresh North Atlantic Swell. Although technically not a perfectly exposed image, one of my favorites all the same. The contrast you see here isn’t made by sliding buttons on a computer, it’s made by the sun - the way it should be.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by ChrisBurkard in Iceland. May be an image of mountain and nature.

node.text: A color pallete that is iconically Westfjords. A perfect study in layers.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo shared by ChrisBurkard on August 08, 2021 tagging @beccaspeak, and @luanasilva__. May be an image of nature.

node.text:
Nothing better than watching someone break through their comfort zone & explore a new realm, especially one previously seen as scary or impossible. 
New work coming soon from an incredible trip in the North Atlantic with these ladies.
Was a pleasure to watch @luanasilva__ @beccaspeak brave cold water, relentless wind and never ending driving to search for late winter surf in these enchanted Islands. 

Shot for @billabong @billabongwomens

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by ChrisBurkard in Iceland. May be an image of nature and snow.

node.text: A good surf trip is still a part of my DNA. It’s what I dream about shooting and often it is the discovery of new waves that will always still draws me to new places. But after awhile the desire to tell deeper more intimate narratives and the stories behind the athlete or the pursuit of simply riding waves has become paramount. Why are people drawn to these experiences? What makes them build a life and identity behind it? These are often questions I am asking myself when considering a new story to tell. To me the greatest exploration of human achievement is found in studying humans relationship to nature and how we immerse ourselves in it.

node.text: As I prepare to pack my bike back up and head to Iceland next month once again for a bikepacking trip through the Westfjords. I am reminded of my 2020 expedition through the interior of the country traveling from the furthest East to West Point. The fact that is was done during Covid shutdown with special exemptions to enter the country felt very unique and special. More than that, this is Incredible crew, @ericbatty @adammorka @emilybatty1 , made it truly memorable. We planned for a year and then 2020 happened and it gave is all a greater appreciation of what it means to take full advantage of an opportunity when it comes, because you never know when the world may shut down again

node.text:
This Friday 6-10pm we will be having a film screening of our award winning film ‘Unnur’ along with Mylo and the new Arc of Aleutia. Ill also be doing a Q&A. This will be at our Pismo Beach CA Studio. 

This will be an outdoor event with live music and food trucks. Come and hang.. 10 dollars at the door or you can buy online in my bio link. 🤙

See you there!

node.text:
I never went to college, I quit school at 19 to my parents dismay and pursued photography. In many ways travel & the experiences it created became a great but very harsh teacher. The sacrifice it required I wasn’t fully prepared for. 

WAYWARD is a book about taking an unconventional path to find your way.

I’d consider those years the most important of my life. The photographs were just bonus to the experiences, cultures and the people that I crossed paths with. From the distant shores of Kamchatka to remote islands in the Arctic and beyond. Frostbite to heatstroke, Russian jail cells to snowed in cabins… this is finally my thoughts on the last decade.

‘Wayward’ is available for preorder now and publishes in November . Grab your copy at www.ChrisBurkard.com

node.text:
An excerpt from my teammate  @thatisgus journal entries from our Iceland Winter Crossing. 

 “We either make it, or we don’t”

I’ve never been interested in being the first to do anything on a bike. 

Not recently at least. 

My reason to ride has always come from the chance encounters with strangers that arrive through the rain at an intersection in Pontiac, or Krusevo, or Goose Bay. The opportunity to share a few words before the traffic light changes, or the bar closes, or the sunrises on another day and I pedal on toward the next intersection, bar stool, or sunrise. 

My rides aren’t technical, or exhausting, or breathtaking. More often than not the places I find myself drawn to are at the end of long, straight, featureless roads. Mundane portals that lead to mundane places. 

I don’t ride to escape from the world, but rather to immerse myself in it. 

But alas, we have been amidst a pandemic. And with no where to rush to the increased time spent alone changed the way I experienced the bike. From using it as a tool to seek out others to a tool to dive deeper into myself. I found myself wanting to know what I was capable of. 

So I said yes when Chris asked if I wanted to attempt to cross Iceland by bike in the winter. There’s no traffic lights, or barstools out there and the only stranger I’d be meeting I’d be stuck with. 

There's no place for meandering conversation, only methodical execution. And we would have to rely on each other, not in the way I had relied on a teammate to grab bottles or a stranger to spin a yarn, rather rely on them to take care of themselves, and me when the time calls for it. 

It was an objective completely out of character, requiring a set of skills I’d either let wither to near oblivion or never possessed to begin with. It felt like a return to a more traditional sporting pursuit, and I was ready for it. 

A simple test with a definitive answer - We either make it, or we don’t.

@hereorthereabouts @rebeccarusch 
@fezzari_bicycles @oldmanmountainracks @chamoisbuttr @45nrth @srammtb @revelatedesigns @zippspeed @66north @infinitybikeseat @icelandair
